articles.headline: Next Leader May Echo Maliki, but Iraqis Hope for New Results
articles.snippet: During the American occupation, Haider al-Abadi, a Shiite chosen to be Iraq’s next prime minister, resisted the idea of reconciliation with Sunnis, but some hope he can break the mold of recent leaders and govern in an inclusive way.
articles.abstract: During the American occupation, Haider al-Abadi, a Shiite chosen to be Iraq’s next prime minister, resisted the idea of reconciliation with Sunnis, but some hope he can break the mold of recent leaders and govern in an inclusive way.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — The last time the United States pushed Iraqis to choose a new prime minister who could unite the country to confront a sectarian civil war was in 2006, and the Iraqis chose Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. The result was another civil war. This time, with the country again on the edge of collapse, they have chosen Haider al-Abadi.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Caught Backsliding, Standard Chartered Is Fined $300 Million
articles.snippet: Standard Chartered will also be prevented from processing payments in dollars for “high-risk retail business clients” in Hong Kong, with the bank’s monitor determining which clients are “high risk.”
articles.abstract: Standard Chartered will also be prevented from processing payments in dollars for “high-risk retail business clients” in Hong Kong, with the bank’s monitor determining which clients are “high risk.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:34 p.m. | It took $667 million in fines and a promise to behave for the British bank Standard Chartered to emerge from the regulatory spotlight. All it took to return there was its failure to fully keep that promise.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Uber Picks David Plouffe to Wage Regulatory Fight
articles.snippet: Mr. Plouffe, who ran President Obama’s 2008 campaign, will be in charge of policy and strategy for the car service start-up.
articles.abstract: Mr. Plouffe, who ran President Obama’s 2008 campaign, will be in charge of policy and strategy for the car service start-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber wants your vote of support. And it has hired a campaign manager to win you over.

articles.headline: On Senate Menu, Bean Soup and a Serving of ‘Hyperpartisanship’
articles.snippet: Comity has been eroding for years in Washington, but to see the fractured Senate in a more personal way, one has only to visit the exclusive dining room.
articles.abstract: Comity has been eroding for years in Washington, but to see the fractured Senate in a more personal way, one has only to visit the exclusive dining room.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A generation ago, here in the Senate Dining Room, Senators Mike Mansfield, a Democrat of Montana and majority leader, and George Aiken, a Republican of Vermont, met most mornings to have breakfast together, a scene almost unimaginable in today’s polarized climate.

articles.headline: Grappling With the Cost of Corporate Gadflies
articles.snippet: Three activists specialize in bringing shareholder proposals at annual meetings, but these proposals are costing companies tens of millions of dollars, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor.
articles.abstract: Three activists specialize in bringing shareholder proposals at annual meetings, but these proposals are costing companies tens of millions of dollars, writes Steven Davidoff Solomon in the Deal Professor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Corporate America is being held hostage by three people you have probably never heard of.

articles.headline: Plenty of Room at the Top of Ukraine’s Fading Rebellion
articles.snippet: In what separatist officials call the “Ukrainianization” of the leadership, almost all the original Russian leaders of the rebellion have resigned and gone home, replaced by Ukrainians of dubious qualifications.
articles.abstract: In what separatist officials call the “Ukrainianization” of the leadership, almost all the original Russian leaders of the rebellion have resigned and gone home, replaced by Ukrainians of dubious qualifications.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — To outward appearances, Fyodor D. Berezin is the picture of a senior military commander. He wears camouflage, has bodyguards and confidently gives orders as the newly named deputy defense minister of the separatist Donetsk People’s Republic. Yet, just four months ago he was an obscure author of 18 science fiction novels, one play and a dozen or so short stories.

articles.headline: RadioShack in Need of Rewiring
articles.snippet: RadioShack’s ubiquitous stores flourished when consumers fixed their own gadgets. Now, the chain is trying out brighter, more inviting stores to lure shoppers.
articles.abstract: RadioShack’s ubiquitous stores flourished when consumers fixed their own gadgets. Now, the chain is trying out brighter, more inviting stores to lure shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1971, Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak hawked tiny machines called Blue Boxes that allowed long-distance phone calls to be made free by mimicking certain tones.

articles.headline: Shooting Accounts Differ as Holder Schedules Visit to Ferguson
articles.snippet: Witnesses to the shooting of a black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., have given investigators sharply conflicting accounts. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is scheduled to visit Wednesday.
articles.abstract: Witnesses to the shooting of a black teenager by a white police officer in Ferguson, Mo., have given investigators sharply conflicting accounts. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. is scheduled to visit Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — As a county grand jury prepared to hear evidence on Wednesday in the shooting death of a black teenager by a white police officer that touched off 10 days of unrest here, witnesses have given investigators sharply conflicting accounts of the killing.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Shared Vision, Varying Styles
articles.snippet: As African-Americans have praised Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s outspokenness on Ferguson, Mo., and lament President Obama’s restraint, the White House has denied any substantive distance between the two.
articles.abstract: As African-Americans have praised Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s outspokenness on Ferguson, Mo., and lament President Obama’s restraint, the White House has denied any substantive distance between the two.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two men in open-collar shirts sat facing each other, papers and a BlackBerry strewn on a coffee table, sober looks on both their faces. One leaned forward, gesturing with his left hand, clearly doing the talking. The other sat back in his chair, two fingers pressed to his temple as he listened intently.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: Clashes Erupt as Liberia Sets an Ebola Quarantine
articles.snippet: Soldiers and the police blocked roads to a neighborhood of tens of thousands of people in Monrovia, Liberia’s capital, and residents hurled rocks and stormed barricades trying to break out.
articles.abstract: Soldiers and the police blocked roads to a neighborhood of tens of thousands of people in Monrovia, Liberia’s capital, and residents hurled rocks and stormed barricades trying to break out.
articles.lead_paragraph: MONROVIA, Liberia — Soldiers and police officers in riot gear blocked the roads. Even the waterfront was cordoned off, with the coast guard stopping residents from setting out in canoes. The entire neighborhood, a sprawling slum with tens of thousands of people, awoke Wednesday morning to find that it was under strict quarantine in the government’s halting fight against Ebola.
